Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that Carlow Regional Technical College failed to advise students for the 1997-1998 academic year of the increase in registration fees to £250; if his attention has further been drawn to the fact that students who turned up for registration on 30 September 1997, and who had previously paid £150, had to pay a further £100 on the spot; his views on whether the college was at fault and that it would be more appropriate for the £100 to be paid in instalments; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : On 30 July last, I announced that the standardised charge levied by third level colleges for examinations, registration and student services could be increased from £150 to £250. Details of the increase were conveyed to third level colleges and widely publicised in the national press at the time.

I understand from Carlow Regional Technical College that the college authorities did not advise individual students returning to the college of the increased charge. I also understand that, while any student who was in a position to pay the increase on registration day did so, those students who experienced difficulties in meeting the increase were registered and allowed a special facility whereby they undertook to pay the £100 increase by 15 January 1998.
Students who are eligible for maintenance grants under the means tested support schemes do not have to pay this charge.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether his Department has taken steps to eliminate differences between estimates used in decision making, building contract prices and final completed costs; and the value of each of these costings in respect of the most recent ten completed building projects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : I take it the Deputy's question relates to the information contained in the Appropriation Account for 1996 in relation to primary school buildings.

It has been the policy of successive Ministers for Education to approve primary school building projects at the pre-planning stage based on estimated costs, and in the knowledge that estimates would change as planning work was undertaken. This policy was considered prudent given the significant backlog of primary schools needing major capital works, and the costs associated with bringing the projects through the planning stages before seeking ministerial approval. The clear danger with this latter course of action is that too much of the budget would be spent on planning costs at the expense of providing much-needed accommodation.
I have noted the comments of the Comptroller and Auditor General and will be looking at ways of effecting improvements to the system.
The detailed information in relation to individual projects cannot be compiled in the time available for reply and will be sent to the Deputy as quickly as possible.

Qst.Quest: whether physical education will become an examination subject at leaving certificate level; the arrangements, if any, which he has put in place to introduce physical education as a subject; if so, the timescale involved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)

An aspect of physical education is currently provided within the leaving certificate applied programme for examination under the leisure studies module.
Proposals to undertake a pilot project in physical education at junior cycle are being actively considered by my Department. The project will address the issue of assessment in physical education.
This project will inform decision making on the development of an effective programme of physical education at leaving certificate and the appropriate timescale for implementing any proposed changes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : I intend taking Questions Nos. 259 and 287 together.

The assistance provided by my Department towards the provision of caretaking and secretarial services in second-level schools reflects the different school management and ownership arrangements at second level.
In the case of voluntary secondary schools in the free education scheme, all schools with 200 or more pupils receive financial assistance towards the cost of both caretaking and clerical services.
In the case of vocational schools and colleges, caretaking and clerical staff are allocated to vocational education committees on a scheme
wide basis. It is a matter for the vocational education committee to deploy staff in the best manner possible to meet the needs of the committee and its schools.
All schools in the community and comprehensive school sector have been provided with clerical and caretaking services.

MainHeading.P: Fee charging schools are generally not eligible for assistance towards the provision of secretarial and caretaking services. However, there is a small number of fee charging schools of the Protestant tradition which also quality for assistance from my Department in respect of these services.

Qst.Quest: the amendments, if any, he proposes to bring forward to modify the school curriculum to place more emphasis on cultural and artistic activities as outlined in An Action Programme for the Millennium; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : A review of the primary curriculum is being finalised by the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment (NCCA) at present. Arts education, which encompasses visual arts, music, drama, dance and literature, will form a key element in the revised curriculum which will be implemented in primary schools in the years ahead.

At second level greater emphasis is being placed on cultural and artistic activities in various curricular programmes. At junior certificate level the NCCA is developing short courses in dance and drama. The transition year programme enables schools to develop specific cultural and artistic programmes to meet their own local needs. At leaving certificate level modular programmes continue to be developed in arts education for the new leaving certificate applied programme. The art syllabus for leaving certificate is being revised.

At both primary and second levels, cultural activities are being emphasised in the various syllabi for Irish, History and Geography. Consultations with the Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands form an important part of my consideration of these developments.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : The selection and enrolment of pupils in primary and second level schools is, in the first instance, the responsibility of individual school managerial authorities. Speaker.hpid: Mr. Higgins (Mayo) Mr. Higgins (Mayo)
Speaker.P: (Mayo)asked the Minister for Education and Science if he has agreed to the retention of teachers at schools (details supplied) in County Mayo which were scheduled to lose a teacher each. [15605/97]

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : The Deputy will be pleased to know that four of the five schools mentioned by him have retained the staffing allocations which they had for the 1996-97 school year.

MainHeading.P: I regret, however, that the other school referred to by him lost a teaching post for the 1997-98 school year. The school in question had an enrolment of 84 pupils on 30 September 1996, a decrease of ten pupils on the previous year's figure. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and two assistant teachers for the 1997-98 school year.

Qst.Quest: whether his attention has been drawn to the deep concern of both the board of management and the parents' association at the lack of progress in implementing the phase two development of Castleknock community college, Dublin 15; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : The architectural planning for phase two of Castleknock community college has been initiated and the vocational education committee's design team has been requested to submit the outline sketch scheme for the proposed development. When the submission has been found to be satisfactory, the project will proceed to stage three of planning which is the developed sketch scheme.

The project will continue to be accorded a high priority in my Department and every effort will be made to ensure that the planning of the project is completed as quickly as possible with a view to inviting tenders immediately and building starting as quickly as possible.

Qst.Quest: if he will sanction the appointment of a classroom assistant to help the work of the class teacher in view of the particular special needs of deaf children at the Sacred Heart primary school, Ballymahon, County Longford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : Since my appointment as Minister for Education, I have allocated an additional 15 child care assistant posts to the primary sector. These posts were allocated on the basis of priority of need as determined by my Department following consideration of data submitted by applicant schools.

As Minister for Education, I have to consider a wide range of competing demands across the special needs area. I have to establish priorities and respond to these demands as effectively as possible within available resources. I am at present reviewing provision across the special needs area, including the child care area, to ensure that all available resources are deployed to best effect. I can assure the Deputies that the needs of St. Patrick's national school, Drumcondra, and the Sacred Heart primary school, Ballymahon, will be fully considered in this context.

Qst.Quest: the grant aid which is available from his Department to enable students participate in the horticultural course in Warrenstown Agricultural College, County Westmeath.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : There is no grant aid available to students pursuing the horticultural course at Warrenstown Agricultural College under the schemes of student support operated by my Department.
However, I understand that Teagasc awards grant aid to such students.

Qst.Quest: when funding will be made available for Lough Mourne Oliver Plunkett school, Lough Mourne, Castleblayney, County Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : Oliver Plunkett national school, Louth Mourne, Castleblayney, applied for grant aid towards works to the school. A report is due to be furnished shortly from the Office of Public Works in Dundalk on the extent of the work required and the estimated cost. On receipt of this report, a decision will be made regarding funding and my Department will be in touch with the school authorities.

Qst.Quest: when he will allocate the remedial teacher on an ex-quota basis to Coláiste Mhuire secondary school, Mullingar, County Westmeath in view of the fact that this school currently has a pupil population of 663, and there are a number of pupils who would benefit from such an appointment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: : I am very conscious of the need to improve the remedial teacher service in our secondary schools.

I am sure that the Deputy will appreciate that there are many competing demands for increased funding in all sectors of education. These demands are considered within the overall budgetary constraints and I can assure the Deputy that the position of this school will be kept under review and will be considered when next it is possible to allocate additional ex-quota remedial posts.
